thread.title: Every eye in the Mets universe turns to Jacob deGrom
thread.title_full: Every eye in the Mets universe turns to Jacob deGrom | New York Post

author: Dan Martin
title: Every eye in the Mets universe turns to Jacob deGrom
text:
Jacob deGrom didn’t shy away from facing Dodgers lefty Clayton Kershaw in Game 1 of the NLDS, outdueling the three-time Cy Young award winner to give the Mets the early lead in the series.
On Thursday, thanks to Kershaw’s bounce-back performance in the Dodgers’ 3-1 win in Game 4, deGrom will get a chance to go up against the Dodgers’ other Cy Young award winner, Zack Greinke, this time with even more on the line in a decisive Game 5.
“We’ve got our horse going,” Lucas Duda said of deGrom.
Travis d’Arnaud, who will catch deGrom Thursday, sounded extremely confident in the right-hander.
“It’s because of what he’s done since the day he’s been here,” d’Arnaud said of the 2014 Rookie of the Year. “He’s got the perfect personality for this moment. He’s a simple man who likes to keep things simple and just go out there and pitch. He’s been stellar for us all year.”
The Mets need one more stellar outing.
DeGrom briefly got the attention of some of the Citi Field crowd when he began throwing in the bullpen during Tuesday’s defeat while starter Steven Matz was still on the mound.
But unlike with the Blue Jays on Monday, when manager John Gibbons brought in presumptive ALDS Game 5 starter David Price in the fifth inning, deGrom didn’t get on the field against Los Angeles and instead will start Thursday.
Mets manager Terry Collins said afterward deGrom might have pitched if Matz had been knocked out early, but once Matz survived a three-run third, deGrom threw a regular bullpen session.
After Matz was unable to close out the Dodgers at home, deGrom now faces even more pressure. Yet if recent history is any indication, deGrom should be up to the challenge.
He certainly didn’t back down in the series opener, pitching seven scoreless innings, striking out 13 along the way. In that game, though, he was working with at least a small margin for error, with the knowledge the series couldn’t be won or lost that night.
At Chavez Ravine on Thursday, that won’t be the case.
So the veteran of 53 career major-league starts will pitch the biggest game of his career.
If the Mets are looking for some positives heading into Thursday, deGrom’s outstanding outing in Game 1 wasn’t the first time he had overpowered the Dodgers this season.
Back on July 26 at Citi Field, the right-hander held Los Angeles scoreless for 7 ²/₃ innings, walking two and fanning eight while getting a no-decision in a 3-2 win.
The Mets’ offense managed to scratch two runs off the Dodgers starter and then another off the bullpen to pick up the win.
That Dodgers starter? Zack Greinke. The Mets would gladly accept the same outcome.
